metadata.title: Photodynamic therapeutic ablation for peripheral pulmonary malignancy via electromagnetic navigation bronchoscopy localization in a hybrid operating room (OR): a pioneering study

sections.abstract: Background: With the aid of electromagnetic navigation bronchoscopy (ENB), it has become possible to approach peripheral lung tumors from the airway. Meanwhile, local ablation using photodynamic therapy (PDT) has shown increasing promise in the realm of lung cancer treatment. The purpose of this study was to explore an alternative ablation method using PDT with SuperDimension ENB localization in a hybrid operating theater. Methods: Our study includes patients with primary or metastatic lung cancer who underwent PDT via ENB in the hybrid operating room (OR) of National Taiwan University Hospital between January 2016 and January 2017. ENB with the SuperDimension Navigation System (7th edition) was performed before PDT ablation to localize the target lesions. PDT ablation was performed with the assistance of intraoperative Dyna-computed tomography (Dyna-CT). Tumor response was evaluated by CT 3 months after the procedure. Results: Three patients underwent lung interstitial PDT via the aid of ENB during the study period. The mean size of the nodules was 21.3 mm. The mean navigation time was 14.3 minutes. In all cases, the target pulmonary nodule was ablated by PDT successfully. No major procedure-related complications occurred. One patient suffered from skin hypersensitivity one month after the procedure. The follow-up CT showed significant tumor shrinkage for all the patients. They were all discharged without incident a few days after the procedure as scheduled. Conclusions: PDT with SuperDimension ENB guidance in the hybrid OR is a novel and feasible approach to control peripheral lung malignancy.
sections.methods: A prospectively maintained database was reviewed to identify all patients who underwent PDT via ENB from January 2016 to January 2017. Inclusion required lung tumors (not endobronchial) and medical suitability for PDT ablation after ENB localization. Exclusions: age <18 years; leukopenia (WBC <3,500/mm3) or thrombocytopenia (platelets <100,000/mm3); chronic renal insufficiency with serum creatinine >2.5 mg/dL; grade 3-4 liver function test elevations or bilirubin >1.5 mg/dL; pregnancy or lactation. Under general anesthesia, nodules were localized using the SuperDimension Navigation System (7th edition). A locatable electromagnetic guide and extended working catheter were used; after localization, the guide was removed and a PDT probe was inserted through the catheter. Dyna-CT in the hybrid OR confirmed probe position. Photofrin 2 mg/kg IV was given 48 hours pre-procedure. Illumination: 630-nm light, 200 J/cm, LUNG mode (2,000 mW) for 500 seconds using a Diomed 630-nm diode laser and optical fiber. Post-operative care followed standard practice. Tumor response at 3 months by CT was categorized as complete remission (CR), partial remission (PR), no change (NC), or progressive disease (PD).
sections.results: Three patients (1 male, 2 female) with malignant lung tumors (2 colon cancer metastases, 1 lung adenocarcinoma) underwent ENB-guided interstitial PDT. Mean nodule size was 21.3 mm. Mean navigation time was 14.3 minutes. Localization and ablation were successful in all cases. No major procedure-related complications occurred. One patient developed grade I skin hypersensitivity one month after the procedure. All patients were discharged without incident. At 3 months, CT showed tumor shrinkage: 1 CR and 2 PR.

retrieval.summary_tldr: In a 3-patient case series, ENB-guided interstitial Photofrin PDT achieved 100% objective response (1 CR, 2 PR) at 3 months with no major complications; 1 patient had grade I photosensitivity.
retrieval.clinical_relevance: Demonstrates technical feasibility and initial safety of ENB-guided PDT for peripheral pulmonary malignancies using hybrid OR imaging.
